segment.source: This article describes how to create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that play audio in the background.
segment.target: This article describes how to create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps that play audio in the background.

segment.source: This means that even after the user has minimized your app, returned to the home screen, or has navigated away from your app in some other way, your app can continue to play audio.
segment.target: This means that even after the user has minimized your app, returned to the home screen, or has navigated away from your app in some other way, your app can continue to play audio.

segment.source: Scenarios for background audio playback include:
segment.target: Scenarios for background audio playback include:

segment.source: Long-running playlists: The user briefly brings up a foreground app to select and start a playlist, after which the user expects the playlist to continue playing in the background.
segment.target: Long-running playlists: The user briefly brings up a foreground app to select and start a playlist, after which the user expects the playlist to continue playing in the background.

segment.source: Using task switcher: The user briefly brings up a foreground app to start playing audio, then switches to another open app using the task switcher.
segment.target: Using task switcher: The user briefly brings up a foreground app to start playing audio, then switches to another open app using the task switcher.

segment.source: The user expects the audio to continue playing in the background.
segment.target: The user expects the audio to continue playing in the background.

segment.source: Background audio architecture
segment.target: Background audio architecture

segment.source: An app performing background playback consists of two processes.
segment.target: An app performing background playback consists of two processes.

segment.source: The first process is the main app, which contains the app UI and client logic, running in the foreground.
segment.target: The first process is the main app, which contains the app UI and client logic, running in the foreground.

segment.source: The second process is the background playback task, which implements IBackgroundTask like all UWP app background tasks.
segment.target: The second process is the background playback task, which implements IBackgroundTask like all UWP app background tasks.

segment.source: The background task contains the audio playback logic and background services.
segment.target: The background task contains the audio playback logic and background services.

segment.source: The background task communicates with the system through the System Media Transport Controls.
segment.target: The background task communicates with the system through the System Media Transport Controls.

segment.source: MediaPlayer
segment.target: MediaPlayer

segment.source: The Windows.Media.Playback namespace contains APIs used to play audio in the background.
segment.target: The Windows.Media.Playback namespace contains APIs used to play audio in the background.

segment.source: There is a single instance of MediaPlayer per app through which playback occurs.
segment.target: There is a single instance of MediaPlayer per app through which playback occurs.

segment.source: Your background audio app calls methods and sets properties on the MediaPlayer class to set the current track, start playback, pause, fast forward, rewind, and so on.
segment.target: Your background audio app calls methods and sets properties on the MediaPlayer class to set the current track, start playback, pause, fast forward, rewind, and so on.

segment.source: The media player object instance is always accessed through the BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current property.
segment.target: The media player object instance is always accessed through the BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current property.

segment.source: MediaPlayer Proxy and Stub
segment.target: MediaPlayer Proxy and Stub

segment.source: When BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current is accessed from your app's background process, the MediaPlayer instance is activated in the background task host and can be manipulated directly.
segment.target: When BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current is accessed from your app's background process, the MediaPlayer instance is activated in the background task host and can be manipulated directly.

segment.source: When BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current is accessed from the foreground application, the MediaPlayer instance that is returned is actually a proxy that communicates with a stub in the background process.
segment.target: When BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current is accessed from the foreground application, the MediaPlayer instance that is returned is actually a proxy that communicates with a stub in the background process.

segment.source: This stub communicates with the actual MediaPlayer instance, which is also hosted in the background process.
segment.target: This stub communicates with the actual MediaPlayer instance, which is also hosted in the background process.

segment.source: Both the foreground and background process can access most of the properties of the MediaPlayer instance, with the exception of MediaPlayer.Source and MediaPlayer.SystemMediaTransportControls which can only be accessed from the background process.
segment.target: Both the foreground and background process can access most of the properties of the MediaPlayer instance, with the exception of MediaPlayer.Source and MediaPlayer.SystemMediaTransportControls which can only be accessed from the background process.

segment.source: The foreground app and the background process can both receive notifications of media-specific events like MediaOpened, MediaEnded, and MediaFailed.
segment.target: The foreground app and the background process can both receive notifications of media-specific events like MediaOpened, MediaEnded, and MediaFailed.

segment.source: Playback Lists
segment.target: Playback Lists

segment.source: A common scenario for background audio applications is to play multiple items in a row.
segment.target: A common scenario for background audio applications is to play multiple items in a row.

segment.source: This is most easily accomplished in your background process by using a MediaPlaybackList object, which can be set as a source on the MediaPlayer by assigning it to the MediaPlayer.Source property.
segment.target: This is most easily accomplished in your background process by using a MediaPlaybackList object, which can be set as a source on the MediaPlayer by assigning it to the MediaPlayer.Source property.

segment.source: It is not possible to access a MediaPlaybackList from the foreground process that was set in the background process.
segment.target: It is not possible to access a MediaPlaybackList from the foreground process that was set in the background process.

segment.source: System Media Transport Controls
segment.target: System Media Transport Controls

segment.source: A user may control audio playback without directly using your app's UI through means such as Bluetooth devices, SmartGlass, and the System Media Transport Controls.
segment.target: A user may control audio playback without directly using your app's UI through means such as Bluetooth devices, SmartGlass, and the System Media Transport Controls.

segment.source: Your background task uses the SystemMediaTransportControls class to subscribe to these user-initiated system events.
segment.target: Your background task uses the SystemMediaTransportControls class to subscribe to these user-initiated system events.

segment.source: To get a SystemMediaTransportControls instance from within the background process, use the MediaPlayer.SystemMediaTransportControls property.
segment.target: To get a SystemMediaTransportControls instance from within the background process, use the MediaPlayer.SystemMediaTransportControls property.

segment.source: Foreground apps get an instance of the class by calling SystemMediaTransportControls.GetForCurrentView, but the instance returned is a foreground-only instance that does not relate to the background task.
segment.target: Foreground apps get an instance of the class by calling SystemMediaTransportControls.GetForCurrentView, but the instance returned is a foreground-only instance that does not relate to the background task.

segment.source: Sending Messages Between Tasks
segment.target: Sending Messages Between Tasks

segment.source: There are times when you will want to communicate between the two processes of a background audio app.
segment.target: There are times when you will want to communicate between the two processes of a background audio app.

segment.source: For example, you might want the background task to notify the foreground task when a new track starts playing, and then send the new song title to the foreground task to display on the screen.
segment.target: For example, you might want the background task to notify the foreground task when a new track starts playing, and then send the new song title to the foreground task to display on the screen.

segment.source: A simple communication mechanism raises events in both the foreground and background processes.
segment.target: A simple communication mechanism raises events in both the foreground and background processes.

segment.source: The SendMessageToForeground and SendMessageToBackground methods each invoke events in the corresponding process.
segment.target: The SendMessageToForeground and SendMessageToBackground methods each invoke events in the corresponding process.

segment.source: Messages can be received by subscribing to the MessageReceivedFromBackground and MessageReceivedFromForeground events.
segment.target: Messages can be received by subscribing to the MessageReceivedFromBackground and MessageReceivedFromForeground events.

segment.source: Data can be passed as an argument to the send message methods that are then passed into the message received event handlers.
segment.target: Data can be passed as an argument to the send message methods that are then passed into the message received event handlers.

segment.source: Pass data using the ValueSet class.
segment.target: Pass data using the ValueSet class.

segment.source: This class is a dictionary that contains a string as a key and other value types as values.
segment.target: This class is a dictionary that contains a string as a key and other value types as values.

segment.source: You can pass simple value types such as integers, strings, and booleans.
segment.target: You can pass simple value types such as integers, strings, and booleans.

segment.source: Background Task Life Cycle
segment.target: Background Task Life Cycle

segment.source: The lifetime of a background task is closely tied to your app's current playback status.
segment.target: The lifetime of a background task is closely tied to your app's current playback status.

segment.source: For example, when the user pauses audio playback, the system may terminate or cancel your app depending on the circumstances.
segment.target: For example, when the user pauses audio playback, the system may terminate or cancel your app depending on the circumstances.

segment.source: After a period of time without audio playback, the system may automatically shut down the background task.
segment.target: After a period of time without audio playback, the system may automatically shut down the background task.

segment.source: The IBackgroundTask.Run method is called the first time your app accesses either BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current from code running in the foreground app or when you register a handler for the MessageReceivedFromBackground event, whichever occurs first.
segment.target: The IBackgroundTask.Run method is called the first time your app accesses either BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current from code running in the foreground app or when you register a handler for the MessageReceivedFromBackground event, whichever occurs first.

segment.source: It is recommended that you register for the message received handler before calling BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current for the first time so that the foreground app doesn't miss any messages sent from the background process.
segment.target: It is recommended that you register for the message received handler before calling BackgroundMediaPlayer.Current for the first time so that the foreground app doesn't miss any messages sent from the background process.

segment.source: To keep the background task alive, your app must request a BackgroundTaskDeferral from within the Run method and call BackgroundTaskDeferral.Complete when the task instance receives the Canceled or Completed events.
segment.target: To keep the background task alive, your app must request a BackgroundTaskDeferral from within the Run method and call BackgroundTaskDeferral.Complete when the task instance receives the Canceled or Completed events.

segment.source: Do not loop or wait in the Run method because this consumes resources and may cause your app's background task to be terminated by the system.
segment.target: Do not loop or wait in the Run method because this consumes resources and may cause your app's background task to be terminated by the system.

segment.source: Your background task gets the Completed event when the Run method is completed and deferral is not requested.
segment.target: Your background task gets the Completed event when the Run method is completed and deferral is not requested.

segment.source: In some cases, when your app gets the Canceled event, it can be also followed by the Completed event.
segment.target: In some cases, when your app gets the Canceled event, it can be also followed by the Completed event.

segment.source: Your task may receive a Canceled event while Run is executing, so be sure to manage this potential concurrence.
segment.target: Your task may receive a Canceled event while Run is executing, so be sure to manage this potential concurrence.

segment.source: System policies for background audio task lifetime
segment.target: System policies for background audio task lifetime

segment.source: The following policies help determine how the system manages the lifetime of background audio tasks.
segment.target: The following policies help determine how the system manages the lifetime of background audio tasks.

segment.source: Exclusivity
segment.target: Exclusivity

segment.source: If enabled, this sub-policy limits the number of background audio tasks to be at most 1 at any given time.
segment.target: If enabled, this sub-policy limits the number of background audio tasks to be at most 1 at any given time.

segment.source: It is enabled on Mobile and other non-Desktop SKUs.
segment.target: It is enabled on Mobile and other non-Desktop SKUs.

segment.source: Inactivity Timeout
segment.target: Inactivity Timeout

segment.source: Due to resource constraints, the system may terminate your background task after a period of inactivity.
segment.target: Due to resource constraints, the system may terminate your background task after a period of inactivity.

segment.source: A background task is considered “inactive” if both of the following conditions are met:
segment.target: A background task is considered “inactive” if both of the following conditions are met:

segment.source: The foreground app is not visible (it is suspended or terminated).
segment.target: The foreground app is not visible (it is suspended or terminated).

segment.source: The background media player is not in the playing state.
segment.target: The background media player is not in the playing state.

segment.source: If both of these conditions are satisfied, the background media system policy will start a timer.
segment.target: If both of these conditions are satisfied, the background media system policy will start a timer.

segment.source: If neither condition has changed when the timer expires, the background media system policy will terminate the background task.
segment.target: If neither condition has changed when the timer expires, the background media system policy will terminate the background task.

segment.source: Shared Lifetime
segment.target: Shared Lifetime

segment.source: If enabled, this sub-policy forces the background task to be dependent on the lifetime of the foreground task.
segment.target: If enabled, this sub-policy forces the background task to be dependent on the lifetime of the foreground task.

segment.source: If the foreground task is shut down, either by the user or the system, the background task will also shut down.
segment.target: If the foreground task is shut down, either by the user or the system, the background task will also shut down.

segment.source: However, note that this does not mean that the foreground is dependent on the background.
segment.target: However, note that this does not mean that the foreground is dependent on the background.

segment.source: If the background task is shut down, this does not force the foreground task to shut down.
segment.target: If the background task is shut down, this does not force the foreground task to shut down.
